# List of supercentenarians from the United States

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Walter_Breuning_April_8%2C_2010.jpg/220px-
Walter_Breuning_April_8%2C_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walter_Breuning_April_8,_2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Walter_Breuning_April_8,_2010.jpg "Enlarge")

[Walter Breuning](/wiki/Walter_Breuning "Walter Breuning"), April 8, 2010, the
second-oldest American-born man on record

This article includes **lists of supercentenarians from the[United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States")** (people from the United States
who have attained the age of at least 110 years). The [Gerontology Research
Group](/wiki/Gerontology_Research_Group "Gerontology Research Group") (GRG),
an organization that tracks supercentenarians and validates longevity claims,
has validated claims of over 700 American
[supercentenarians](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian")[1] and as of 15
July 2018, lists six [verified living American
supercentenarians](/wiki/List_of_oldest_living_people "List of oldest living
people"), the oldest of whom is Lessie Brown, born September 22, 1904, aged
113 years, 296 days.[2] The oldest person ever from the United States was
[Sarah Knauss](/wiki/Sarah_Knauss "Sarah Knauss"), who died on December 30,
1999, aged 119 years, 97 days.[3][4][5][6]

## List of
people[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: List of people")]

### Ann
Pouder[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Ann Pouder")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Ann_Pouder.jpg/160px-
Ann_Pouder.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ann_Pouder.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ann_Pouder.jpg "Enlarge")

Ann Pouder on her 110th birthday; photograph from June, 1919 [National
Geographic Magazine](/wiki/National_Geographic_Magazine "National Geographic
Magazine")

Ann Pouder (née Alexander Poudar) ([London](/wiki/London "London"), [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") April 8, 1807 – [Baltimore,
Maryland](/wiki/Baltimore,_Maryland "Baltimore, Maryland"), [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") July 10, 1917) was one of the
first modernly recognized [British American
supercentenarians](/wiki/British_Americans "British Americans"). Her age at
death was 110 years, 93 days.[76] When Pouder was twelve years old, her family
emigrated to the United States. There she lived the following 98 years of her
life in [Baltimore, Maryland](/wiki/Baltimore,_Maryland "Baltimore,
Maryland"). She married [Nepalese American](/wiki/Nepalese_Americans "Nepalese
Americans") Citizen Alexander Poudar, although became a widow very early and
had no children. Her extreme longevity claim was certified by [Alexander
Graham Bell](/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell "Alexander Graham Bell").[77] In her
last few months, she was bedridden, [blind](/wiki/Blindness "Blindness"), and
almost [deaf](/wiki/Deaf "Deaf"), but her mind remained sharp.[78]

### Florence
Knapp[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Florence Knapp")]

Florence Knapp (October 10, 1873 – January 11, 1988) was, for the last two
weeks of her life, recognized by the [Guinness Book of World
Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records") as the oldest
person in the world.[79]

Born in [Lansdale, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Lansdale,_Pennsylvania "Lansdale,
Pennsylvania"), she lived in nearby Montgomery Square much of her life and
came from a large and long-lived family, eight of her siblings dying in their
80s and 90s and one sister reaching [age 108](/wiki/Centenarian
"Centenarian").

By October 1987, when she was honored by the Pennsylvania legislature, she was
recognized by Guinness as the oldest person in the United States, and the
death of [Anna Eliza Williams](/wiki/Anna_Eliza_Williams "Anna Eliza
Williams") on December 27, 1987, meant that Knapp became the oldest verified
living person. Her death, aged 114 years 93 days, just 15 days after, meant
that she never appeared in a Guinness Book as the oldest living person.

Her death caused some confusion as to who her successor was, with Guinness
recognition and press publicity alighting first on Orpha Nusbaum (August 1875
– March 1988), who died before the 1989 edition's deadline, then Birdie May
Vogt (August 1876 – July 1989), who appeared in the 1989 edition's main text,
then [Jeanne Calment](/wiki/Jeanne_Calment "Jeanne Calment"), mentioned in the
addenda section, and finally in November 1988 on [Carrie C.
White](/wiki/Carrie_C._White "Carrie C. White"), whose claim to birth in
November 1874 was accepted. However, with recent census research calling
White's authentication into question, Calment may very well have been Florence
Knapp's actual immediate successor.

### Ettie Mae
Greene[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Ettie Mae Greene")]

Ettie Mae Greene née Thomas (September 8, 1877 – February 26, 1992) was an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States")
[supercentenarian](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian") who was
recognized by [Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness
World Records") as the 'oldest living American' in 1991 (later, the
[SSA](/wiki/Social_Security_Administration "Social Security Administration")
study would replace her with [Lucy Hannah](/wiki/Lucy_Hannah "Lucy Hannah"),
who was apparently older). She was born in [Wayside, West
Virginia](/wiki/Wayside,_West_Virginia "Wayside, West Virginia"), and worked
as a seamstress and a farmer.[80] Greene died of a cold at the Springfield
Comprehensive Care Center in [Springfield, West
Virginia](/wiki/Springfield,_West_Virginia "Springfield, West Virginia"). At
the time of her death at the age of 114 years, 171 days, she had nine children
(four of whom she had outlived), 21 grandchildren, 47 great-grandchildren and
37 great-great-grandchildren.[80] She still holds the record for being the
[oldest person](/wiki/List_of_the_verified_oldest_people "List of the verified
oldest people") in the state of [West Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West
Virginia").

### Wilhelmina
Kott[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Wilhelmina Kott")]

Wilhelmina Kott née Geringer (March 7, 1880 – September 6, 1994)[81] was an
American supercentenarian recognized by Guinness World Records as the 'oldest
living American' in its 1995 edition,[63] following the death of [Margaret
Skeete](/wiki/Margaret_Skeete "Margaret Skeete"). She was born in Peru,
Illinois, as one of 16 children to George and Sophia Geringer. She moved to
Chicago in 1881, where she lived almost her entire life. She married Charles
Kott in 1899.[63] She died on September 6, 1994, aged 114 years 183 days.

### Mary
Bidwell[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Mary Bidwell")]

Mary Electa Bidwell née Nobel (May 19, 1881– April 25, 1996)[82] was an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States")
[supercentenarian](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian"). She died at age
114 years, 342 days on April 25, 1996. She is the oldest person ever to die in
[Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut").[83][84][85]

Her parents were Charles Woodruff Bidwell and Alice Beach Nobel.[84] She was a
descendant of John Bidwell, one of the founders of [Hartford,
Connecticut](/wiki/Hartford,_Connecticut "Hartford, Connecticut"). Bidwell
worked as a teacher in a [one-room school house](/wiki/One-room_school_house
"One-room school house") for six years. She married Charles Hubbell Bidwell, a
distant cousin, in 1906.[83]

Bidwell lived on her own in [North Haven,
Connecticut](/wiki/North_Haven,_Connecticut "North Haven, Connecticut"), until
she was 110. Bidwell died at the Arden House, a nursing home in [Hamden,
Connecticut](/wiki/Hamden,_Connecticut "Hamden, Connecticut").[82][85]

### Maggie
Barnes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Maggie Barnes")]

Maggie Pauline Barnes née Hinnant (March 6, 1882 – January 19, 1998)[86] was
an American supercentenarian. She was a resident of [Johnston County, North
Carolina](/wiki/Johnston_County,_North_Carolina "Johnston County, North
Carolina"). Barnes died from complications following a minor foot
infection.[87] Barnes, who was born to a slave and married a [tenant
farmer](/wiki/Tenant_farmer "Tenant farmer"), was survived by four children;
11 of her children preceded her in death.[87]

Some dispute exists as to her date of birth. Though the 1882 date is written
in the family's bible, the 1900 US Census lists her as having been born in
1881, and her [marriage license](/wiki/Marriage_license "Marriage license")
says she was born in 1880.[87] Authenticating to the latest of those dates,
Barnes was 115 years, 319 days old when she died.

Barnes is the oldest person ever in U.S. state of [North
Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina") on record.

### Mae
Harrington[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Mae Harrington")]

Mae Harrington (née Maxwell; January 20, 1889 – December 29, 2002) was an
American supercentenarian who became the world's oldest living person upon the
death of [Adelina Domingues](/wiki/Adelina_Domingues "Adelina Domingues").
Harrington was also the oldest living American and the oldest person ever from
the state of New York, breaking the record held since the 1920s by then
world's oldest person [Delina Filkins](/wiki/Delina_Filkins "Delina Filkins"),
also 113, but her own record was subsequently broken on May 28, 2005 by Grace
Thaxton, who was born in the state before moving to and dying in Kentucky.
Because her age was not authenticated during her lifetime, the public
recognition she was due went to another 113-year-old, Mary Parr (January 29,
1889 – October 29, 2002), who was born nine days after her, dying two months
before her, as her age was only validated posthumously.[88]

### Mary
Christian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Mary Christian")]

Mary Dorothy Christian (née Perry, June 12, 1889 – April 20, 2003) was an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States")
[supercentenarian](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian") who became the
[oldest recognized person in the United States](/wiki/Oldest_people "Oldest
people") at age 113 upon the death of 113-year-old [Mae
Harrington](/wiki/Mae_Harrington "Mae Harrington") and was succeeded in this
title by another 113-year-old, [Elena Slough](/wiki/Elena_Slough "Elena
Slough"). Perry was born in [Taunton,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Taunton,_Massachusetts "Taunton, Massachusetts") to
parents whose name had been [anglicized](/wiki/Anglicism "Anglicism") from
_Perreira_ (she was of [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") descent). She
spent much of her life in [California](/wiki/California "California"), where
she died in a [San Pablo, California](/wiki/San_Pablo,_California "San Pablo,
California") nursing home at 113 years and 312 days.[64][89]

### Elena
Slough[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Elena Slough")]

Elena Proctor Slough née Rodenbaugh (July 4, 1889 – October 5, 2003)[65] was
the oldest recognized person in the United States from the death of Mary
Christian on April 20, 2003, until Slough's own death, aged 114 years 93 days,
six months later. After her death, the oldest recognized person in the United
States was Charlotte Benkner.[65]

Born in [Horsham, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Horsham,_Pennsylvania "Horsham,
Pennsylvania"), she married twice and had children by each marriage. Her
90-year-old daughter died three days before her, at the same [Cape May, New
Jersey](/wiki/Cape_May,_New_Jersey "Cape May, New Jersey") nursing home. Some
sources date her birth to 1888, but the oldest records state that she was born
in 1889.[90]

### Charlotte
Benkner[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Charlotte Benkner")]

Charlotte Benkner (née Enterlein; November 16, 1889 – May 14,
2004)[91][92][93][94] was an [American](/wiki/United_States "United States")
[supercentenarian](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian") and [the oldest
verified living person](/wiki/Oldest_people "Oldest people") from [Mitoyo
Kawate](/wiki/Mitoyo_Kawate "Mitoyo Kawate")'s death in 2003 until sufficient
documentation was found to validate the age of [Ramona Trinidad Iglesias-
Jordan](/wiki/Ramona_Trinidad_Iglesias-Jordan "Ramona Trinidad Iglesias-
Jordan") of [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") in March 2004.[91]
The subsequent recognition of [María Capovilla](/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Capovilla
"María Capovilla") of [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") in December 2005
moved Benkner down to third place at the time of her death.[92][93]

Benkner was born in [Leipzig](/wiki/Leipzig "Leipzig"), Germany, and
[emigrated to the U.S.](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to
the United States") in 1896. She grew up in [Peekskill, New
York](/wiki/Peekskill,_New_York "Peekskill, New York"), where her family ran
the _Albert Hotel_ , and as a young woman once met then [President of the
United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore
Roosevelt").[94][95] On her 1908 marriage to Karl Benkner, she moved west,
living in [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania") and
[Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") before retiring to [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona
"Arizona"). Already a supercentenarian and the oldest person in Arizona,
Benkner returned to Ohio to live in [North Lima](/wiki/North_Lima,_Ohio "North
Lima, Ohio").[94] She became the oldest recognized person in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") when 114-year-old [Elena
Slough](/wiki/Elena_Slough "Elena Slough") died in October 2003.[65] She lived
with her sister Tillie O'Hare (the youngest of the siblings), whom she once
cared for when their parents were running the hotel, until Tillie (born
February 15, 1904) died, just three weeks shy of becoming a
[centenarian](/wiki/Centenarian "Centenarian"), on January 25, 2004.[95]
Benkner survived her sister by only four months, dying at age [114 years 180
days](/wiki/List_of_the_verified_oldest_people "List of the verified oldest
people") after she was briefly hospitalized in [Youngstown,
Ohio](/wiki/Youngstown,_Ohio "Youngstown, Ohio"), and was buried in
Peekskill.[91][92]

### Emma Verona
Johnston[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Emma Verona Johnston")]

Emma Verona Johnston (née Calhoun) (August 6, 1890 – December 1, 2004) was an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States")
[supercentenarian](/wiki/Supercentenarian "Supercentenarian") recognized as
the "oldest living American" from Charlotte Benkner's death in May 2004 until
her own death almost 7 months later at age 114 years, 117 days. Johnston was
born in [Indianola, Iowa](/wiki/Indianola,_Iowa "Indianola, Iowa") to a large
family.[96] She was the oldest living graduate of [Drake
University](/wiki/Drake_University "Drake University"), where she was a member
of the Class of 1912.[97]

At age 98, she moved from [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa "Iowa") to [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio
"Ohio") in order to live with her daughter and son-in-law. She continued to be
in good health even after turning 110, still being able to walk up steps, and
was also alert and able to engage in conversations.[2]

Charlotte Benkner's death on May 14, 2004 left Johnston as [the oldest
documented person](/wiki/List_of_the_verified_oldest_people "List of the
verified oldest people") in the United States. She died in [Worthington,
Ohio](/wiki/Worthington,_Ohio "Worthington, Ohio") on December 1, 2004.[96]

### Grace
Thaxton[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Grace Thaxton")]

Grace Thaxton (née Menges) (June 18, 1891 - July 6, 2005) was one of oldest
people in the United States until her death on July 6, 2005, age 114 years and
18 days. She became [New York state's all-time
recordholder](/wiki/Melva_Radcliffe "Melva Radcliffe") on May 28, 2005, aged
113 years 344 days, breaking the record set by [Mae
Harrington](/wiki/Mae_Harrington "Mae Harrington") in December 2002.[98]

Thaxton almost lived to see her son Robert (July 12, 1915 – 2011) turn 90, six
days after her death. Thaxton's mother (1860–1969) lived to 109.[99]

### Bettie
Wilson[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Bettie Wilson")]

Bettie Antry Wilson née Rutherford (September 13, 1890 – February 13,
2006)[100] was thought to be the oldest verified living person in the United
States upon the death of 114-year-old Emma Verona Johnston on December 1, 2004
until the subsequent verification of [Elizabeth Bolden](/wiki/Elizabeth_Bolden
"Elizabeth Bolden"). Both were born in the rural South—where they lived less
than 100 miles apart.

Born of freed slaves, Solomon and Delia Rutherford, she is the oldest resident
of the state of Mississippi ever recorded (the previous record was 113 years,
12 days set in 1994). In late April 2005, Wilson moved into a new home funded
by donations.

Wilson celebrated her 115th birthday in September 2005, at which time she
ranked as the third-oldest living person in the world.

Wilson died at her [New Albany](/wiki/New_Albany,_Mississippi "New Albany,
Mississippi") home on February 13, 2006, aged 115 years, 153 days. She was
survived by her son, five grandchildren, 46 great-grandchildren, 95 great-
great-grandchildren and 38 great-great-great grandchildren.[100]

### Thomas Nelson,
Sr.[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Thomas Nelson, Sr.")]

Thomas D. Nelson, Sr. (July 8, 1895 – January 9, 2007) was, at age 111, the
oldest living man in the United States and the second-oldest man in the world
from December 7, 2006 (the death of [Moses Hardy](/wiki/Moses_Hardy "Moses
Hardy")), for one month until his own death, aged 111 years, 185 days.

He had been living in [Port Arthur, Texas](/wiki/Port_Arthur,_Texas "Port
Arthur, Texas"), since the early 1930s. He opened a candy shop in the
mid-1930s, and worked there for more than 60 years.[101][102]

### Arbella
Ewing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Arbella Ewing")]

Arbella Ewing (née Perkins) (March 13, 1894 – March 22, 2008)[51][103] was, at
the time of her death at age 114, [the third-oldest living person in the
world](/wiki/Oldest_people "Oldest people") behind [Edna
Parker](/wiki/Edna_Parker "Edna Parker") of United States and [Maria de
Jesus](/wiki/Maria_de_Jesus "Maria de Jesus") of Portugal, the second-oldest
person in the United States and the oldest living [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American").[104]

Ewing, the fourth of 12 children, grew up in [Streetman,
Texas](/wiki/Streetman,_Texas "Streetman, Texas"), and married Frank Ewing in
1915, after which she moved to [South Dallas](/wiki/South_Dallas "South
Dallas"). Her former house is still located in South Dallas today. She had a
sister named Annie, who was born in 1904 and was 103 at the time of her death.
When she was an adult, she worked in a local bikeshop in Streetman. Her great-
grandparents were slaves in [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi").
After marrying Frank Ewing, they had a daughter, named Claudia, who died in
1970. The Ewing family stated she was a gem in the family according to [The
Dallas Morning News](/wiki/The_Dallas_Morning_News "The Dallas Morning News").
She lived in her own home in Dallas until the age of 113, after breaking her
hip at her birthday party, she was moved into a personal care home, where she
eventually died nine days after having reached the age of 114. The people
close to her attributed her [longevity](/wiki/Longevity "Longevity") to
positive thinking.[104][105][106]

### George
Francis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: George Francis")]

George Rene Francis (June 6, 1896 – December 27, 2008)[107][108][109] was an
American supercentenarian and the joint second-oldest living man in the world,
together with Englishman [Henry Allingham](/wiki/Henry_Allingham "Henry
Allingham"), until Francis's death aged 112 years, 204 days. He was also the
oldest living man in the United States, following the death of [Antonio
Pierro](/wiki/Antonio_Pierro "Antonio Pierro") on February 8, 2007. Francis
was from [New Orleans, Louisiana](/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana "New Orleans,
Louisiana"), but since 1949 lived in [Sacramento,
California](/wiki/Sacramento,_California "Sacramento, California"), where a
local newspaper published a poem that Francis enjoyed reciting to friends and
the public throughout his life.[110] He credited his longevity to nature, and
enjoyed a rich diet of pork, eggs, milk and lard. He gave up smoking cigars at
the age of 75.[111]

Francis attempted to join the army in World War I but was rejected for service
in 1918 as being too short and small (he weighed only about 100 pounds (45.35
kg)). Despite this, he later was a boxer before becoming a barber and then a
chauffeur.[107] Francis claimed to have met [Louis
Armstrong](/wiki/Louis_Armstrong "Louis Armstrong") and [Booker T.
Washington](/wiki/Booker_T._Washington "Booker T. Washington") and to have
seen [Babe Ruth](/wiki/Babe_Ruth "Babe Ruth") hit a home run. His wife died in
1964.

### Shelby
Harris[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_supercentenarians_from_the_United_States&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Shelby Harris")]

Shelby Harris (March 31, 1901 – July 25, 2012),[112] an [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American"), was the oldest verified
man in the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") (since the
death of [Walter Breuning](/wiki/Walter_Breuning "Walter Breuning") on April
14, 2011), the third-oldest man in the world and [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois
"Illinois")'s oldest living person at the time of his death.[112][113][114]

A native of [Ayrshire, Indiana](/wiki/Ayrshire,_Indiana "Ayrshire, Indiana"),
Harris worked in coal mines and a [foundry](/wiki/Foundry "Foundry"). At 41 he
joined the Army for [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), but a
broken ankle ended his training. A [deacon](/wiki/Deacon "Deacon") of his
church until he was 102, Harris entered a [Rock
Island](/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois "Rock Island, Illinois") nursing home at
105. At his death he was a great-great-great-grandfather, his youngest
grandson was 57 years old.[115] Harris died on July 25, 2012, aged 111 years,
116 days.[112]
